General thread for talking about what's good and what's not good in the kitchen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18750150
sous vide are good because a) they're generally pretty precise and b) you don't lose any of the nutrients n shit
I personally think they're a bit of a waste of time for the home cook and you're better off getting a grill or spit or something, but if you've got the budget and cooking is a dominant hobby for you, go for it

in a similar vein, what do you guys use mixer wise? specifically for 1-5kg batches
I got a taste for making pastries and such in a Hobart mixer when I was doing a cooking course, to the point my old hand-beater doesn't cut it anymore, but I ain't paying 8000AUD for one and I don't trust women to steer me right on alternatives, which is 99% of articles and shit I've seen

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18750150
I think the best advice I got was buy equipment for food you cook.
I have not ever used my slow cooker I got for free or about half my pots and pan's I also got for free.
I used my cake pan 2 times in 3 years.

I use my 20cm stainless pan everyday and my 30cm cast iron about 4 times a week and a small and big pot for boiling stuff.
Sheet pan 4-6 times a week and cutting board everyday.
Use my kettle, toaster, blender and stick blender and that's it for appliances.

Half the shit in my cupboards are just a waste of space I didn't buy.

Wow man, you are retarded. It literally floats and doesn't mix with the water so it can't possibly do anything.
>the 500º pan doesn't give a shit about your 42º degree refrigerator temperature
Wow, you are retarded. Most fridges are 35°, the inside of your house is 70°, and the steak is going up to 140. These retarded positions would be excusable if all we could do was ponder these questions and had no way to find out the truth. But you can literally just watch a video or test it for yourself and find out that you're wrong.

I was very fat as a teenager. My cousin's kid was having a birthday party, and they were just chucking some stuff on the grill. Since there were a lot of people and they were all over the place, plates were placed out all around the house and the yard for people to grab food. Thus meant my parents couldn't really keep an eye on my consumption of food, like they usually do.

I downed 6 loaded hamburgers (as much cheese and bacon as patty), 5 bratwurst sandwiches, chips, a lot of soda, amd several slices of cake. Somehow I didn't actually feel too terrible in the moment, but just as we were leaving I started to feel queasy.

I had trouble falling asleep from the stomach ache. Eventually I did, but hours later (still in he dead of night) something inside me stirred violently and it awoke me. I had to rush naked to the bathroom and slammed my ass down on the toilet seat, where I proceeded to spew an ungodly amount of brown water from my asshole. This, combined with having consumed enough sodium earlier to have killed a horse, meant that as I sat there spewing forth a waterfall from my ass it felt like thick boiling poison was flowing through every one of my veins, a truly horrifying feeling. My stomach felt like someone was pumping it full of air to bursting point, and after that it happened.

Undigested chunks came flying out in an unholy cacophony. My body completely refused what I had crammed into it, and was just letting it all out. I spent HOURS on that toilet, not wanting to push because my asshole was incredibly sore and in tremendous pain, but needing to push because otherwise my stomach would act up and get stabbing pains. I unironically cried. After all the chunks had evacuated, I was left trying to push out a mostly clear, thick slime.

I washed my ass on the bidet (even the very gentle stream of water on my asshole stung by then) and I crawled back into bed teary eyed, feeling like what I can only asume violent anal rape by an elephant does, and passed out.

Man last night something fucked me up awful and I'm not sure what I'm experiencing. I had two cube steaks with some mushrooms, some cheese, a little jerkey for a snack later, then sipped on some bourbon before bed. I do this all the time, trying to trim down a little so I can pig out for Christmas. These are normal eating patterns for me when I'm cutting. Last night I woke up at about 2:30 with what felt like lava/battery acid erupting from my chest. It was the worst acid reflux I've ever experienced. Didnt habe to throw up or poop, just horrible acid. I was looking up symptoms and it seemed like GERD maybe. Can you get that any time?
Anyway, It was so painful I was tearing up. I went to my living room and sat in a recliner to try to keep my esophagus elevated. It helped a bit, but it just kept going. I tried to go throw up, but it was like 8f outside, so I hurried back in quick. I decides to eat some bread, and it actually did help calm my stomach down. I ended up eating a whole round of banana nut bread. If it helped, it helped, so I just fucking ate it.
Woke up this morning and it's still happening. Took some pepto, a couple tums, nothing is helping. Just horrible gas, burping, farting, and acid geysers coming from my stomach. I'm at work and it's absolute hell. I have no idea why this is happening, but I assume it's dietary, but I've never had anything like this happen before. It's so fucking uncomfortable. I'd rather just diarrhea and vomit instead, it's way easier to deal with.

Anon I see the issue with this, but I don't think that's what bothers me. Ground coffee will offgas bulk of it's co2 in first couple of days, and co2 is not what makes coffee fresh. Secondly I'm not expecting it to be fresh, just passable after being in a drawer for a year. Since the pods are nitrogen purged that should be a good way to store it.
>>>>>>>>>>>>
I did some experiments with leftover k-cups I had.
Coffee ones had 5-6 g of coffee, so in no way can it make more than a 6oz cup from a pod.
Tea had 2.5g of tea, which is more than a typical 2g teabag, should be able to make a cup.
Dicking around with machine, I found that the water comes out fairly cold and heats up mid way thru the brew.
The brew is also very fast, maybe a minute, which is not long enough to extract coffee or tea.
>>>>>>>>>>>>
As far as the instapod machine that can do both nespresso and k-cup.
Nespresso pod holds 5-6g of coffee also, and minimum size for the espresso on it is 2oz.
Which again for a decent espresso simulacrum it should make around 1oz of beverage.
The original machines make 40g shots, which is closer to what you'd want.
It also costs $200, and that's just not worth it for a half ass machine.
>>>>>>>>>>>>
This leaves me with either a nespresso, the original style not the weird spinny one, or maybe the illy pod machine and tea bags for tea.
>inb4 why pods

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18748475
Trans Canada Brewing in Winnipeg
Rebellion Brewing in Regina
Haven't been to any breweries in Ontario that really blew me away but most of them are alright. Best I've been to was probably Tooth and Nail Brewing in Ottawa. The waitress also wasn't wearing a bra and there was a nice bakery across the road.
In Quebec, Frontibus and Naufrager in Gaspesie both make some great beers. Fin du Monde also comes in tallboys in Quebec and you can buy them for 4$ at grocery stores. Probably my favourite beer province not so much for going to breweries but almost all the beer is good and you can buy it anywhere.
Only been to one brewery in New Brunswick, Four Rivers in Bathurst. It was okay but nothing special, which is kind of the impression I've gotten of most NB beers.
Only been to PEI Brewing on PEI. Nothing special.
In Nova Scotia, the best brewery I went to was 2 Crows in Halifax, but I think most of the beer I had from Halifax breweries was pretty good. Schoolhouse Brewery in Windsor was pretty good too.
All the breweries I've visited in Alberta have been kind of eh, but I'm sure there's a good one out there. I had a rye beer from Medicine Hat Brewing which was alright.
In the Yukon, Winterlong is probably the most consistently good but Woodcutters Blanket has made some okay beers and Polarity does some good ones too. Yukon Brewing has been on a downward trend in quality the last three years.
Haven't had any beer from NWT, Nunavut or Newfoundland.
Another of my favourite breweries in BC is Backroads Brewing in Nelson. Also like Category 12 in Saanichton and Driftwood in Victoria (pic related is one of my all time favourite beers).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18748475
>>18748507
Pile'O'Bones (SK), Unibroue (QC), Fuggles & Warlock (BC), and Grizzly Paw (AB) are my favorite Canadian breweries.

I'm pretty much only familiar with SK/AB/BC/YT beer as I've lived in all four locations for a time. I find Rebellion mediocre for SK breweries. Pile'O'Bones, Nokomis, 9 Mile, Malty National, and Bushwakker are all better. I think I have tried every brewery in SK, and those are the best ones and they are very good. For a fairly small province SK has remarkably good food and drink.

YT is small enough that I tried everything and nothing was memorable.

AB I haven't delved into that hard. Everything from Calgary was bad. Grizzly Paw from Canmore is very good, especially on tap. Jasper Brewing I have only had on tap and it was consistently good, but nothing stellar.

The BC beer scene is far more diverse than SK but overwhelmingly disappointing. I've had Dageraad, Strange Fellows, Tailout, Phillips, Hoyne, Lighthouse, Townsite, Persephone, Whistler Brewing, Fuggles & Warlock, Torchlight, Nelson Brewing, Granville Island, Over Time, Grist & Mash, Fernie Brewing, Arrowhead, Whitetooth, Mt. Begbie, Field House, and a bunch of others that I can't even remember. Most of these I have had beer on tap at the breweries themselves.

Fuggles&Warlock and Dageraad are best overall BC breweries.
Field House has one standout blackberry/blueberry sour.
Fernie Brewing has one standout seasonal pumpkin ale.
Whistler has one standout seasonal winter dunkel (sweet orange&spice dessert beer).
Granville Island has a night light summer raspberry ale.
The rest are forgettable and can't even do a good basic brown, amber, etc.

They probably only tell you to do 350 because overheating an empty enameled cast iron pan can cause it to crack. If you want it to polymerize it it needs to be much higher.

Personally I wouldn't worry about it, I never seasoned my rim and it's fine. If you're really worried just rub a thin layer of oil if you're storing it for a long time. Any rust that appears on the rim is surface level anyways, it isn't like it's gonna eat your dutch oven alive.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18747784
>season top
Does it have iron exposed on the lid's rim too? The main reason for this is to buffer for when steam collects and drips when it's closed. It can get rusted from sitting in the sink too but it's usually only surfacelevel. As far as the oil, they don't know what oil you're using (many people use lard/grease) so they have to put a low general temp for safety reasons. I would bump up the temp higher. Oil has a tendency to bud or form pools even if it's not an excessive amount, so let it heat up and after like 20 minutes pull it out, wipe and spread the oil, then put it back in to finish polymerizing. Stickiness is a sign of too much oil or not enough fusing.
>>18747941
Some have exposed metal on the rim like picrel

posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18750641
I think he's referring to differential thermal expansion. If you take a cold peice of cast iron and put it directly onto a full blast burner it can cause the metal at the top and bottom to expand at different rates causing it to crack. You should always preheat your cast iron slowly before putting it in the oven to season anyways since it will speed the process up significantly.

>>18746943
County of origin, type of sugar cane byproduct used (cane juice, sugar, molasses, other), still used (pot, column, both) and aging are the most important factors. Good luck finding most of that out with your average rum. Agricole is a legal term and usually means cane juice and a vegetal and herbal flavor. Age means little because it's so hot in the tropics and some of the barrel houses are at high altitude.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18739526
>Will pressed purerh and white cakes continue to age after pressing
Yes they will, they are typically aged after pressing though they may age faster if loose.

>will they benefit from it?
Depends on if you prefer the aged taste or young taste. In general you should thing of the aged form as being different vs strictly being better. Fresh young sheng and well aged sheng are practically two different teas. Some really harsh or funky young puerh debatably are strait up better with aging though.

>leave them in the pantry now for a few years, will they benefit from it?
Fully aging tea takes a long time and is a slow processes in most conditions (e.g. semi aged sheng is 10ish years old, "fully" aged sheng is 20+ years old, white tea ages a bit faster). A few years in dry conditions will just make sheng a bit less green and "fresh", mellow out some of the bright floral notes of the white tea, and clear up some of the funk on shou or liu bao (probably the most useful scenario here for only aging 3 years). Starting out I would not buy tea solely to age but if you buy more tea than you drink there is nothing wrong with aging some of it. That's what I do at least.

>leave them in the pantry
Just be careful about the conditions there. You want the tea to be somewhere where it will not pick up smells. A lot of western puerh drinkers just store their tea in ziplock bags or sealed containers. The best way to store tea for aging in the west is a more complex topic and is still somewhat a mater of debate. Here are some blog posts that will put you in the right direction if you want to go down that rabbit whole.
https://teadb.org/low-barrier-puerh-storage-solutions-for-casual-puerh-drinkers/
https://teadb.org/simple-home-storage-solutions/
https://teadb.org/pumidors-101-designing-maintain-your-own-pumidor/
https://teadb.org/puerh-storage/

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18745906
>how long should the steeps be?
Start out at like 10-15 seconds and extend with subsequent brews
>can i brew grampa style
Yeah works great for ripes, use around 4-6 grams depending on how big your mug is

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18745906
>the leaves tasted like burnt cookies or caramelised sugar, which I quite enjoyed
Nice that's the classic v93 flavor profile.
Grampa style, refill with boiling water when you drink halfway down, the first brew isn't super strong but when you refill you will get a pretty concentrated flavor. Give it a quick stir with a spoon when you refill to improve the extraction.
Brewing gongfu you just need to a get a feel for how much leaf to use and how long to push each extraction, you can typically brew ripe teas much longer and get a more concentrated flavor that way

Probably not the best way to make it if you are especially sensitive to bitter things though.

>my wife wants to know how hard it is to get tea that isn't grown in polluted soil
Not too hard, Japanese tea is pretty clean, lots of the indian tea plantations are fine. China can have issues but the mass market exported stuff is usually okay, the tea factories are at least in theory required to do testing of their products. typically china has issues with low quality counterfeit and adulterated teas being sold domestically. But i guess if you want to be extra paranoid you can skip chinese teas.
The tea that the different shops in the pastebin sell are generally pretty clean and safe. The worst offenders with tea seem to usually be off brand cheap teabags from discount stores.

>>18748030
I have no idea about heath effects, positive or negative. /tea/ generally tries to discourage people from focusing too much about health claims and focus more on enjoying tea.
What i can say is that as someone with a sensitive stomach certain teas with high tannin contents like indian assam and english breakfast blends can bother my stomach a bit, especially if they are brewed for too long (say longer than 3-4 minutes for western style)
Chinese black teas, oolongs, indian Darjeeling, green teas and other varieties don't cause this issue and its most pronounced with finely ground teabag tea.
The only real documented cases of tea causing health problems we have dug up involve Tibetans that boil tea stems all day from low quality tea and drink it, and a few crazy people in the USA who were brewing and drinking 100-200 teabags a day of the cheapest stuff possible getting excessive fluoride levels.

>>18749837
Hei cha, means dark tea in chinese
Liubao is kind of like ripe puer but with more emphasis on earthly flavors, woody, soil, root celler, that sort of thing. I think its often better than ripe puer.
A liubao that has spent at least a few years in Wuzhou after production is key to understand the essence of liubao. Three cranes is my favorite factory and one of the largest producers
https://yunnansourcing.com/collections/guangxi-liu-bao-tea/products/2011-three-cranes-15010-liu-bao-tea
Tian jian is typically somewhere between a black tea and and oolong flavor wise, they are generally either pretty smokey and peaty or not smoked/lightly smoked. Age isint as important as long as its 4+ years old but more age doesn't hurt either.
Light to no smoke
https://yunnansourcing.com/collections/hunan-tian-jian-tea/products/2013-cha-yu-lin-gong-jian-tea-hunan-anhua-hei-cha?variant=19802705199207
Smoke
https://yunnansourcing.com/collections/hunan-tian-jian-tea/products/2016-cha-yu-lin-wang-xi-village-wild-tian-jian-hei-cha-in-basket
Liuan is another basket aged tea. Can be pretty intense when its young, a few years (4-5) to mellow out helps it reach is final profile rich, warm gets almost medicinal with enough long humid storage.
https://purplecloudteahouse.com/ has a few baskets but they are on vacation for a another week or two, chawang shop also has some, i would go for first grade or special grade with at least 4 years of age
Continued...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18750034
...
Fu brick is partially fermented and inoculated with a fungus called golden flowers, its supposed to have heath effects but who knows, it isn't bad fornyou at least and it doesn't affect the tea flavor too much, fu brick has notes of aged raw puer, vanilla sometimes some slight breaddy yeasty aspects and hints of black tea produced oolong style.
https://yunnansourcing.com/collections/hunan-fu-brick-tea/products/2017-yun-tai-mountain-sentinel-mountain-fu-zhuan-brick-tea
I haven't gotten around to quian lang yet so idunno.
https://yunnansourcing.com/collections/hunan-qian-liang-and-shi-liang-tea/products/2012-gao-jian-shan-qian-liang-cha-hunan-hei-cha-tea
Hei cha all fantastic stuff that is still undervalued in the current market but prices are steadily increasing, stock up before it gets as expensive as puer.
Special credit to yunnan sourcing for having a fantastic selection especially of high end fu brick productions (i think it's his favorite kind of tea) their prices are extremely competitive with Chinese domestic prices right now unlike his puer which tends to get overmarket after a few years.
I can't emphasize enough that liubao isn't really liubao if it hasn't sent at least 5 years in Guanxi / Wuzhou or Malaysia. I mean it is, but its not the same, the humid basket storage is a vital part of it developing its signature flavor profile.

>>18752041
We are both Mexican living in Mexico eating mexican food.

I am from Sinaloa and she is from Guadalajara, so we are mixing some recipes.

Here is something that she discovered. There is a place in Culiacan named Palomar de los pobres. Just some grilled meat, nothing special, but the beans they serve are pretty good.
It has been a mystery trying to find the trick to make those. However, the first time she tried, she told me that they used “manteca de puerco”, pork lard. When we got back to Guadalajara, she made beans with pork lard and had the same fucking flavour.

Not the best pic but this is what I found.

It is funny because all the people from Culiacan tried to replicate those beans but my wife told me that it is a Guadalajara style.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18752246
Protein powder is just food, it's not significantly different from just eating a piece of chicken breast aside from missing a few micronutrients and being easier/more convenient to prepare/put down. If you already eat lots of protein (ie you eat a shitton of chicken or drink a lot of milk etc) then adding/replacing a meal with a protein shake is probably not going to have a huge effect.

But most people are not deliberate enough with their nutrition to be maxed out like that so as a general rule it should help. If you're underweight/average weight and want to grow a bit, having a scoop or two of protein a day in addition to what you already eat would generally be beneficial. If you're overweight you could instead try replacing one of your meals with a protein shake.

Ikizukuri, (roughly translated as "prepared alive" is the preparing of sashimi (raw fish) from live seafood. In this Japanese culinary technique, the most popular sea animal used is fish, but octopus, shrimp, and lobster may also be used.The practice is controversial owing to concerns about the animal's suffering, as it is still alive when served.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
okonomiyaki. i prefer hiroshima style over kansai style but it's up to you

any kind of katsu teishoku (set meal). tonkatsu is the most popular but they're all generally pretty good. also often comes in a curry variety (katsu-curry). if you're looking for crazy flavorful and spicy curry you're in the wrong country, japanese curry is really mild and more soupy but i like it a lot

takoyaki if you're in osaka, not really a "dish" though, more of a snack

unagi (eel)

tsukemen (cold dipping nooldes), amazing during warmer months and have a much more complex flavor profile than ramen IMO

any kind of tempura, i like shrimp and oyster but you can't go wrong with deep fried meat of any kind

umeshi (Japanese plum wine)

>>18751605
can't say how good lidl's one is but i've had some damn good ajvars from jars.
as for making it at home, i don't know how much yugos do it but in bulgaria i'd say there's an 80/20 divide between getting it at the store vs. making it (in favor of getting it at the store). but again, we don't make ajvar here, we make lyutenitsa which is like ajvar but no eggplant and just tomato and peppers.

if it was bland for you, you can try the crumbled feta thing i guess. all the ajvars i've had were sweet, savory and smokey. but lidl sometimes does weird things with its regional products where they end up tasting like some weird amalgamation of each country's variant that isn't quite right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I finally quit after 12 years of nicotine use and I feel completely fine. It was only hell for about a week, and then there were 2 more weeks of constantly thinking about nicotine and having to be sad that I couldn't have anymore. But now it's been a month and I'm completely over it, no more withdrawal symptoms, no more cravings, just feel 100% fine and normal. Except I don't need to keep consuming nicotine in order to be comfortable. I basically can just be comfortable indefinitely. It feels like there's a magical nicotine patch inserted inside my skin and it never runs out, so it just keeps feeding me pleasure and keeping me feeling content. I had no idea I could be like this. It's really awesome.

I always thought that if I quit, my life would basically be hell forever, since I'd always have to keep missing nicotine every day for the rest of my life. I thought it would be like having a wife tragically killed in a car accident and then you always miss her forever. I thought that even though the physical withdrawal could obviously go away, and chemically my brain would go back to normal, I'd never be able to forget the knowledge of how much I love smoking and dipping. I thought since I ate the forbidden fruit of knowledge, I was doomed to nicotine slavery forever.

I just can't express to you guys how fucking crazy it is that the feeling of missing cigarettes and feeling down and "lonely" about quitting, it literally just went away in under a month. I can't believe it was that fucking easy all along, and I just never stuck it out long enough to find this out sooner. I have been an addict for 12 fucking years and wishing I could stop for most of that time. And all along I literally could.

Remember that thread about chocolate containing high levels of heavy metal contamination awhile ago?
https://www.reuters.com/legal/hershey-sued-over-chocolate-containing-heavy-metals-2022-12-29/
>NEW YORK, Dec 29 (Reuters) - Hershey Co (HSY.N) has been sued by a consumer who accused the company of selling dark chocolate that contains harmful levels of lead and cadmium. In a proposed class action filed on Wednesday, Christopher Lazazzaro said he would not have bought or would have paid less for Hershey's Special Dark Mildly Sweet Chocolate, Lily's Extra Dark Chocolate 70% Cocoa and Lily's Extreme Dark Chocolate 85% Cocoa had Hershey disclosed their metals content.

>Hershey did not immediately respond on Thursday to requests for comment on the lawsuit, which was filed in the federal court in Central Islip, New York. Lazazzaro, a resident of Nassau County, New York, sued two weeks after Consumer Reports unveiled the results of scientific testing of 28 dark chocolate bars for lead and cadmium. Hershey's Special Dark bar and Lily's 70% bar were high in lead, and Lily's 85% bar was high in lead and cadmium, the magazine said. Lazazzaro said reasonable consumers would be turned off by such levels because they pose a "serious health risk," and that consumers rely on Hershey to be truthful about ingredients in its products.

>The lawsuit seeks at least $5 million of damages, including at least $500 per transaction under New York law. Hershey bought Lily's for $425 million in June 2021. The case is Lazazzaro v Hershey Co, U.S. District Court, Eastern District of New York, No. 22-07923.

There's a CR petition you can sign to prod for supply chain reform:

I've lived in Chicagoland my whole life, OP. If you like Asian food, I got some recs for you. Most of the best spots are either deep in the suburbs where the Asian people live, or in Chinatown, both Armour square and Argyle in Uptown. Since you only asked for Chicago, I'll stick to city limits. Just know that the Chicagoland suburbs are full of great restaurants and shit to do. This isn't like other major metropolitan areas where the suburbs are pieces of shit, the suburbs here are some of the wealthiest, most affluent places in the entire country, let alone the Midwest.

Here I go with the top Asian restaurants from all major Chicago ethnicities:

Best Chinese:
>Northern cuisine: Northern Tastes in Bridgeport
>Sichuan: Chengdu Impressions in Chinatown
>dim sum: MingHe in Chinatown
>dumplings: Dumpling House in Bridgeport
>hot pot: Happy Lamb (multiple locations)
>modern/white people friendly: Han 202 in Bridgeport and Chinatown

Thai:
>Siam noodle in New Chinatown

Vietnamese:
>Hai Yen in New Chinatown

Korean:
>Cho sun ok in North center

Japanese:
not too many japs live in Chicagoland, so just pick a sushi place in the loop and you should be fine

>>18747382
Try Gene & Georgetti's, if you're looking for steak (they've been around since the early '40s). Also, Bistro Champagne has some great stuff (Lincoln Park area).
For drinks and cocktails, you could do The Redhead Piano Bar, Sparrow, or, if you feel like blowing through a bunch of cash, The Aviary is pretty swanky.
If you're on a budget, I hear that most folks who move out of state find themselves craving Italian beef, so Al's or Portillo's might be worth checking out. For dessert, Margie's Candies.
If you find yourself in an area where the cashiers are located behind bulletproof glass, go elsewhere. Chicago's huge and the violence that people are concerned about is highly concentrated in certain areas of the city. Avoid those and you'll be fine. In most other areas of the city, you'll find that Chicagoans are usually pretty friendly.

posts.com:
Prison Chicken place over at Lasalle, but on the maps it's Micky's Chicken & Fish.
Get off at the Harold Washington Library, make your way down to the famous Federal Prison where 2 guys literally escaped in broad daylight through those tiny ass windows, and you'll see a mexican dive and the Prison Chicken place next door. You can skip the Boni Vito, which has pizza that rivals Little Caeser. Since you won't like it, there might be a Dunkin Donuts or Subway, but there's a nicer pizza place / standing bar called O'Neil's.

You probably don't like beer or stock market so you can skip the bar too and go straight to the Chicken Planet, which has great chicken gyro wraps that used to have a huge ass line around eleven. You can go next door and just get a bento box to go but they won't like you sitting inside eating that chicken. Across the street is the old Billy Goat so you can keep the thin patty / hot dog tradition.

>noooooo it's not special beans that you grinded yourself in a pestle and mortar and put in a french press

Marcus Aurelius agrees with me here when he talked about the way the patricians made such a big fuss about being elite and cultured with foods and clothes, when these are nothing more than tools to nourish us or protect us from the elements. The issue with starbucks isn't that it's not an elite cafe experience, the issue is that it's more expensive than a cigarette habit and you can create the same experience at home.

posts.com:
AP’S ASSESSMENT: False. A spokesperson for the restaurant chain told The Associated Press that this claim has “no validity” and that its concept “is here to stay.” The posts are misrepresenting a 2017 article that discussed some U.S. locations closing between 2012 and 2016, as well as changes the company made to its menu and decor more than a decade ago and a spin-off concept that opened in 2017.

THE FACTS: A misleading claim spread on social media Wednesday that Hooters, the restaurant famous for its scantily-clad waitresses, is shutting down and rebranding due to changing millennial tastes.

“Hooters is shutting down and ‘rebranding,’” one tweet read in part, attributing the alleged move to a study that showed millennials are not interested in breasts. The tweet had received nearly 57,000 likes and more than 18,000 shares as of Wednesday evening.

Another popular tweet with the same claim received more than 5,500 likes and more than 1,000 shares.

But Stephen Brown, a Hooters spokesperson, told The Associated Press that the fast-casual chain has no plans to change up its image.

“There is no validity to this story,” he wrote in an email. “Guests are enjoying this week’s televised sports events at our restaurants across the country and around the world in record numbers, accompanied by craveable menu items, cold beer and iconic hospitality. Our concept is here to stay.”

The company also refuted the claim via one of its Twitter accounts, tweeting: “this is the fakest news that has ever newsed.”

In a follow-up post, the Twitter account that first spread the false claim on Wednesday cited an August 2017 article from Complex, which discussed some locations closing and menu changes in prior years, but did not say the entire chain was closing nor rebranding as the posts suggests.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18737346
Nope. You would think so. It's heavily salted lamb meat, so you have to soak it in water for 24-36 hours and then you steam it for 3-5 hours until it's fork tender. You either put some wooden sticks or almond potatoes in the bottom of the pan for the steaming. It renders out an amazing fatty stock which you can use for sauce and if you do the potato version they will still be firm even though they have been boiled for 3-5 hours due to the salt and fat.

At the end you put them in the oven for 10 mins just to get a bit of color. The Rutabaga and carrot mash is sweet and creamy, balancing out the fatty, salty meat. On the side you have a shot of akevit to help against the fat.

Polish fagg here, me and my family cooked pretty much the usual you see in Poland:
>Croquettes (2 types, one with sauerkraut and mushrooms, the other with eggs)
>Pierogies (sauerkraut with mushrooms and russian ones with potatoes and cottage cheese)

>leftover sauerkraut as a side
>bunch of spiced fries made from leftover potatoes
>Couple of cakes and cookies, most of them based around poppy seeds (most of them were too sweet for me, so I gave it a pass)

1 cup of lukewarm water mixes together with 1 package of dry yeast, let that rest for about 10 minutes
after that start pouring flour add like a spoon worth of olive oil, salt and sugar

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18746497
You're right about how you don't need the 48-hour rise, and for that matter you don't need the week-long refrigerated rise.

for me a 2 hour rise at room temperature works totally fine.

You're also right about how you don't need a super wet dough. I have no idea why some recipes say that. In my experience a dough hydration of 50% - 66% works best, but it remains true that a wetter dough will develop gluten better/faster.

And about gluten development, this is actually how "no-knead" doughs work - very wet doughs that you allow to sit at room temp overnight or up to a whole day, which might explain why some recipes say to do the 48 hour rise like you mentioned, but gluten can and will develop even with lower hydration of 50% - 66% if it you simply knead it.

I haven't tried using milk yet but I want to. It would give it better flavor and brown better at oven temperatures. The problem with milk is that if you let it sit out at room temperature for too long it will spoil, and even in the fridge for a few days it'll start to smell and taste pretty unpleasant. Plus I've gathered that whenever you use milk to make bread you should heat the milk to at least 165ºF first to deactivate enzymes that could interfere with the rising of the dough and the yeast or something. Then you gotta let that milk cool back down enough so that the hot liquid doesn't kill the yeast when you mix them in.

>>18746566
Under-working your dough doesn't affect flavor, just texture. Working or kneading the dough develops gluten which makes the bread chewier, stronger (holds together better), and it rises better since the stronger dough can trap tiny air bubbles throughout the dough, while a weaker dough can't trap air bubbles as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18747222
>I have no idea why some recipes say that
Probably because they're trying to make actual pizza dough, instead of something that only approximately resembles pizza dough if you're blind and wearing mittens.
>which might explain
The 48 hr rise that OP is whinging on about is actually the minimum acceptable rise, it's what the chain pizza places use. The good pizza places do a 5-6 day rise. It's purpose is for flavor and to get the correct crumb. If your only goal for your dough is as a sort of modern-day trencher - something to keep your beloved pineapple and corn toppings off the table - then a 2-hr rise is perfectly adequate. Of course, a flour tortilla works just as well, and is a lot less trouble.

First, you need a high protein flour. I recommend Gold Medal All Trumps. If you can't get that, you can use Gold Medal bread flour. Do not use all purpose flour. It can't develop the right amount of gluten. After you get yourself a good high protein flour, you'll want to have between 60 - 65% hydration. Since you're cooking it in a home oven, add a browning agent to the dough. Not very much, between 1 and 1.5% will do. You'll want 1% yeast, 2% salt, and 1 - 1.5% olive oil. If you have a stand mixer, need it on a medium setting for at least 10 minutes. If kneading by hand you have to knead it until it passes the window pane test.

>>18747801
100% high protein flour such as Gold Medal All Trumps or standard GM bread flour. Never use AP flour for pizza dough.
62% warm water (105 - 112°F)
2% salt
1.5% browning agent (only necessary if cooking in typical home oven)
1.5% extra virgin olive oil
1% yeast
In practice:
- 500g flour
- 310ml water
- 10g salt
- 7.5g honey or dark brown sugar
- 7.5ml olive oil
- 5g yeast
Makes 2 16" NY Style pizza doughs

Mix flour and salt together in bowl of your stand mixer set to the lowest setting. In a separate bowl, mix together yeast, browning agent, and 100ml of the warm water, reserving the remainder. Set yeast aside for 5 minutes to bloom. After yeast has bloomed, add the yeast mixture and the remainder of the water to the dry ingredients in the bowl of your stand mixer. Continue to mix until a dough ball forms. Once a dough ball has formed, drizzle oilve oil around the rim of the bowl. Allow dough ball to run on low speed until oil is incorporated into dough ball. Turn mixer off, and scrape down the dough ball and sides. Turn mixer back on and knead on medium high setting for 10 minutes. After 10 minutes, turn mixer back off, scrape down bowl again. Turn mixer back on to medium low, and knead for 5 additional minutes. Afterwards, turn dough ball out onto lightly floured surface. Divide into two equal dough balls of approximately 420g each. Transfer balls into prepared bowls or pizza pans to rise. Use as desired.

>>18746497
Tom Lehmann pizza dough
263 grams bread flour
166 grams water
4 grams salt
2.5 grams olive oil
1.3 grams yeast
Note: Water temperature should be adjusted to give a finished dough at 80 to 85 °F.
This formula produces a somewhat thin crust with a tough, chewy texture.
How to Prepare:
Standard Dough Making Procedure: Put water into the mixing bowl, add the salt and sugar (sugar is optional and helps with browning in lower-temperature home ovens, use equal amounts of salt and sugar if desired), then add the flour and the yeast. Mix at low speed for about 2 minutes, then mix at medium speed until all of the flour has been picked up into the dough. Now add the oil and mix in for 2 minutes at low speed, then mix the dough at medium speed until it develops a smooth, satiny appearance (generally about 8 to 10 minutes using a planetary mixer).

form dough in to a ball and place in a covered bowl 3 times larger than the doug. put in to refrigerator overnight.

it can be used after up to 72 hours of refrigeration with good results.

bring dough out 4 or 5 hours before you want to use it.

every hour fold and shape the dough (turn it in side out).

when dough is at room temp, let rise one hour.

punch down and make pizza as usual.

Here is my expert opinion on a variety of kitchen appliances.

>Pressure cookers
The most versatile kitchen appliances. They can do almost anything, and they do it perfectly every time. Soups, stews, curries, mashed potatoes. They cook rice even better than a dedicated rice cooker does. If you're a lazy bastard and want low effort meals that are delicious and cheap, this is the ultimate choice.

>Open fire
Gas stove or gas grill, with proper cookware, has the highest ceiling for dish complexity. Everything else is a toy by comparison. It can be intimidatingly expensive to get everything you need if you don't already own one, especially when you factor in all of the high end cookware and tools to buy. They require a lot more skill to use properly, but if you love cooking and don't mind spending a lot of time and money, this is the only choice.

>Oven
Most baked goods require ridiculous amounts of preparation and clean up, making ovens one of the least convenient choices. However the "oven baked" texture they can provide is truly unique and worth the effort if you're a "foodie" (read: fatass). If you already have one you might as well put it to use. Also if you're thinking about getting a small countertop one, you might be disappointed, they don't tend to work quite as nicely as a real oven (Even the really expensive ones).

>Microwave
Actually good for reheating leftovers, but that's about it. Even if you're a lazy retard who can't even learn to cook a pot of noodles, a pressure cooker is going to be better overall. Microwaves heat your food unevenly and can't do many types of dishes. In some cases you'll have to take out the food, stir it, and put it back in multiple times - all for a watery, rubbery, chewy meal.

>Air fryers
Gimmick. One of the only things they're actually good at is making french fries, but oven-baked potato wedges kick way more ass. Air fryers are also obnoxiously difficult to clean. I guarantee you it'll collect dust if you buy one.

I think any reputable butcher shop dry ages his beef (= keeps the quarters hanging in the refrigerated room) for at least a couple weeks before selling it.

>had a dry-aged ribeye that was I think 120-day aged and had a sticker price of close to $200 and it just tasted rancid.
it's pretty much like ripened cheese. Some people love the funky aroma of a steak like that. I've never tried a 120-day steak, but I can appreciate the particular taste of a 60-day aged one every once in a while (oddly enough, blue cheese makes me gag, but the cheesy smell of a dry aged steak doesn't bother me).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
a few tips.
Never use matchlite, ever.
Always monitor your heat, this is more important the smaller the grill.
Indirect heat is your friend, once you are happy with meats cook time, you can move over coals and get that finishing sear.
Cheap off brand charcoal is usually garbage, Kingsford original is hard to beat.
Wood adds great flavor but dramatically increases temps inside your grill, just be aware of this fact.
Smoke covered cook surfaces are non stick.
The weber kettle can be used for grilling or BBQ using the snake method, I have grilled on komodos and the green egg, compared to an old smoked out weber kettle, I was not impressed and would buy a weber before any other grill.
You can use almost any hardwood to add smoke, I like pear wood because I have 8 bradford pear trees on my property. Pear wood burns like the sun, in case you ever try it.
If going low and slow, LEAVE THE LID ON, constantly fucking with your grill WILL mess with cook time.
If going hot and fast, don't use the lid, always monitor your food or you will wind up with charred shit fast.

Honestly grilling or bbq just requires a little patience and common sense.

>>18742320
TV series is better and worth its own conclusion, and the movie is amazing and worth its own conclusion. I dont like the recap movies. I think the TV series is superior in sound and music and the ending of the recaps is kind of an anti climax with the changes they made to the scene where madoka talks to homura. But rebellion story is different. It's an all new soundtrack and its addictively good and completely underrated. I wish there was a falcom style remix of one for all in the soundtrack.

IT's impossible to talk about the content of the movie, but you probably heard things about its conclusion. I'll say that whatever your feelings on it, it doesn't feel warrented to say things are unsalvagably bad for fans of madoka. Madoka has constantly been someone who cares about homura and doesn't want her to suffer alone. I guess the best thing I can say about the movie if you have mixed feelings is it left things off between them in a state of equality. They have the capacity, if they chose, to have a serious conversation about their passive agressive struggle to martyr themselves for one another. But like Madoka 1-12 was a triumphant return of the powerful girl after cleansing herself of her own conciets, naiveties, and foolish ambitions, Rebellion story is about a counterattack to that. IT's literally the "strikes back" in japanese from star wars iirc. Homuras story and goal through the 12 episode anime was an abject failure. It needed to be so that madoka could shine brighter in the narrative. But are we really okay with madoka suffering the ultimate painful sacrifice if it means she gets to be free and strong? Is she? Is homura? Madoka the rebellion story is fundamentally the opposite of the narrative of 12, and the entire movie sets this up with a captivating worth watching on animation and painting grounds alone, toy like world. It's also amazing how, after dehuminizing and masculinizing herself in 12, homura recaptures her feminity in this film's theme

the latter. for example:
gyro is obviously doner kebap (döner=γύρος=turning) with pork.
yogurt in greece used to be runny and very tangy, the strained version originated in turkey and the middle east.
I could go on but basically every famous greek dish originated in asia, most often turkey, and spread to greece under ottoman rule.
wikipedia for example lists phyllo, tzatziki, yuvarlakia, eggplant papoutsaki, boureki, meze, dolma, hummus, pita bread, papoutsakia, baklava, kadaifi, halva, loukoumi, and more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18703613
I don't like:

1) Processed cheese. Anyone who puts processsed cheese on a burger should get a firing squad. Unless you're a wagie at a fast food place, there are no excuses for doing this shit, ever.

2) Fried eggs. The sulfur taste of the yolk and the texture of the eggs clashes with the rest. If you made a thin omelette and folded it and put it on the burger that could work for a breakfast burger, but that's about the only reason I can think of.

3) Olives, marinated artichokes or pickled peppers: They're fucking great, especially in sandwiches, but they're too wet and don't pair well with other ingredients.

4) Any kind of weird shit mixed into the ground beef used to make the burger patties. The beef should contain only beef, and perhaps salt. MAYBE you can add black pepper. MAYBE. If the beef is getting old then crust it in garlic powder to mask the taste a bit, but that's only if the beef is on the edge of inedible. Don't drown it in a ton of butter or oil. Put the patties in a little oil to start with, but let them cook in their own fat.

5) Non-western spices/ingredients. Anyone who adds weird goop like gookchang should be given a free helicopter ride.

6) Excessive grease or sauce. I don't like a slimy burger, fuck off with that shit.

7) Fake meat. I don't need to say anything else.
A burger can contain any kind of meat, but it should have meat. Not sure what to call Portobello burgers.

8) Foods which are generally incompatible with the structure of a burger, or which don't pair with burgers well. Overly sweet things, for example. So, no donuts or strudels.

I can't think of anything else, is that a good list?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When I started making burgers at home I realised how little you actually need to make a good burger.
Lots of toppings just overcrowds a burger, makes it sloppy and unstable, you honestly just need 1 strongly flavoured topping.
My top is:
- jalapenos
- pickles (salt ones not vinegar)
- olives (green)
- NO KETCHUP, literally anything is better, I usually like weird shit like remoulade, but even mayo or a generic burger sauce is better than ketchup.
I don't even use cheese sometimes because i can't even taste it in the burger. Unless i use something strong. Irish cheddar actually worked well.
I should try to make the OG too, mustard, onions and meat. That's it. Should be tasty.

>>18744839
Stop repeating this nonsense. It's 2022, and the risk of getting sick from eating ground beef is virtually non-existent. Every restaurant cooks burgers to order, and medium-rare is by far the most popular way people order them. If there was such a big risk people would be getting sick regularly, and if people were getting sick regularly restaurants wouldn't offer to cook burgers that way. But they do, because they aren't. An overcooked burger is just as unappetizing as an overcooked steak, so if you're afraid of eating beef with a little pink in the middle you'd be better off just ordering something else.

I'm not proud of the fact that I've cooked a thousand burgers, but it's part of the job when I'm working the grill, and I can assure you that when I have a $70 steak on the grill next to a $14 burger I'm going to cook both of them exactly how they were ordered. And that's what 99% of all line cooks are going to do. Sometimes mistakes are made, and if it's really busy we'll send out something that was ordered medium rare when it's closer to medium well, but usually we'll poke our head out and/or ask a server if it's a regular like (you) who thinks it's all the same and cross our fingers that we don't get a complaint (and I almost never get complaints).

>>18747197
I can never get the shit to flow. I clean my parts, heat from the other side until the flux turns brown and starts bubbling, but the solder always just beads up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18747228
practice with leaded solder, it's more forgiving. (do so somewhere with good ventilation and wash your hands after)
pre-heat both sides of the joint. heat them evenly from all sides if you can, with a slow sweeping motion. don't just hold the flame in one spot until you see the flux bubble.
while you're soldering keep the heat on the fitting to draw the solder up into it. here it's OK to keep it basically in one spot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18747277
oh and take care not to over-heat the copper. you're soldering, not brazing.

posts.com: Why does dry brining work so well? You would think that salting chicken would draw the moisture out and dry the meat out but it's the total opposite.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18750375
As I understand it
It breaks down and relaxes the muscles.
Then when it doesn't contact as much when it cooks, so the water stays in.

But I could be totally wrong about that

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18750375
It's called osmosis. The water inside the chicken gets drawn out of the cells by the high concentration of salt which dissolves the salt, and then that highly concentrated salt water gets pulled back into the cells since they have a lower concentration of salt. The high concentration of salt that gets drawn back into the chicken will then start to break down the proteins releasing more moisture inside the meat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When you cook meat, the muscle fibers contract which causes the whole thing to basically wring itself dry like a sponge. But when you salt it, the salt absorbs inside the meat, gets into the muscle fibers and damages them so they won't contract so well anymore. So the meat doesn't squeeze itself as strongly in the end.

Aging meat does basically the same thing. As meat ages the muscle fibers naturally decompose, i.e. become damaged and unable to contract well. So does mechanical tenderizing, like beating the meat with a hammer. It all comes down to physical damage.

Searing has always been a out cooking it above temp. And you get a way more even temp and cooking distribution by reverse searing.

Sear after, remember it's only for visual effects. Let it rest for a while, pat it very dry and only then do you sear and watch very carefully so you stop as soon as the crust forms.

posts.com: Is it necessary to brine and or marinade it for many hours in order for the seasoning to penetrate or can I season just before cooking? Thanks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18749204
chiggin's great because you can do either. I think it's best with a ~12hr brine, pat dry and then season/dry rub before roasting, but most of the time I bring a bird home and just season and roast and it's still pretty awesome.

The key is to NOT overcook and you should truss it. Alton Brown and Chef John have good truss advice. Get a good meat thermometer and know where to check the temp. Most of the time I end up way overcooking it and it's still awesome, and the one time I thought I way undercooked it actually ended up perfect.

Roasting a chicken better than the supermarket birds or Boston Market etc is easy but only once you really get it right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I remember middle school health class covering the food pyramid and how even as a child it felt sketchy at best. It's turned upside its head in so many ways. Even going by its min serving recommendations results in ~2100 calories a day. 2s milk (488g, 293cal) + 2s beef steak (170g, 428cal) + 3s mixed veg (30oz, 546cal) + 2s mixed fruit (324g, 194cal) + 6s grain (174g, 660cal) = 2121cal.
It's a categorical simplification that prioritizes ease of sorting over nutritional impact. Consider the analogy: An exercise pyramid that categorizes exercises by dumbbell, barbell, machine, no weights / body weight, etc.. It's stupid.

The truest statement on food health is, and always has been, "Eat a well balanced diet in moderation."
What makes a diet balanced? Depends more on your body than anything else. Sometimes your body needs more of something or doesn't need as much of something. That need, or lack thereof, could be short-, medium-, or long-term.
If your body is low on an essential nutrient (protein, vitamin, acids, etc..) then eat more foods that contribute to that, preferably while keeping your avg caloric intake approximately constant.
If you want to lose weight you don't even have to change the balance of your diet. Just literally eat less of the same diet. Although, if your protein intake would drop too much I recommend altering the diet a bit to prevent that. That and regular exercise will help reducing your muscle loss as you lose weight.

Also for fucks sake, stop thinking of nutrition as something that has to be met every day. It's a rolling average over days, if not weeks. You don't need some crazy diet that has all of your essentials every day. Some days you get more of this and less or none of that. It's all about averages over time. If you really need breakpoints, use 3d and 7d averages.
When I wanted to lose weight I lost an avg of 2 lbs/wk over 4 months even though some days I had ~2500cal because I kept my avg daily intake under my target ~1500cal.

>>18746663
Yes they are. Storing glucose as glycogen requires energy. While yes, the body is perfectly capable of producing glucose from sources that are not carbs it does not store that glucose as glycogen for future use. That glucose goes straight to use as the body requires glucose to operate. It makes no sense for our bodies to spend extra energy to produce excess glugoce that is then stored when you are already missing glucose and have to first inefficiently create glucose from other sources. And when we're talking glycogen stores it's obvious that I'm talking about the large scale stores. Sure small amounts might be stored as a buffer but adults have multiple kg of glycogen when their glycogen stores are full. It's also why everyone loses weight at first on keto even if they eat the same caloric intake. They expens their glycogen stores but can't replenish them. It's also why people gain weight when they stop keto while keeping the same caloric intake. Those same glycogen stores get filled as they eat carbs.

>>18750919
Steamed Eggs vs. Boiled Eggs: What’s the Difference?
A steamed whole egg shares

https://www.masterclass.com/articles/steamed-eggs-recipesimilarities with a boiled egg, but they differ in both process and results. Water vapor gently steams eggs, immediately permeating the shells and heating them thoroughly. By contrast, eggs added to boiling water will temporarily lower the temperature in the pot—this is especially true if the eggs are straight from the refrigerator, rather than already at room temperature—translating to a less efficient cooking method.

You can have hard-steamed eggs and soft-steamed eggs, much like you can have hard-boiled eggs and soft-boiled eggs; however, compared to a boiled egg, the steamed version is more tender, with a creamier yolk, and is easier to peel.

managing herbs is about as easy as it gets gardening-wise. use a nitrogen-rich soil to keep from yellowing and then moderately water weekly. In terms of sun it depends on what you have in there, but typically partial (4-6 hours a day) will be fine for most herbs.

Yes it is that simple for herbs. Most herbs are literally weeds and will take over the grass in a yard if you let them. There's only one commercially produced anymore and it's in this state. It is really strong and pungent, but the whole makes up for the sum of its parts. Everything has to be so over-the-top that they cancel each other out. Very rye bread (pumpernickel), very strong mustard, fresh red onions, and smoked spread liverwurst. Preferably with a dark beer.
Had a friend who fell asleep watching a movie while we were making it, and I gave it to him half passed out. While he was eating it he seemed fine, but then a piece fell out on his lap and he went to eat it. He immediately woke up and said what the fuck is? The individual ingredient is overpowering, but the ensemble kind of cancels each other out.

Yep, it's pork lau lau. It's fatty pork that's steamed with some fatty fish and salt wrapped in luau leaves (the leaves of the taro plant) and then wrapped in ti leaves (a Hawaiian plant). The closest thing to luau is spinach, but the flavor is really different, and then steaming it in the it leaves adds a whole other flavor. It's not really something you can describe if you haven't tried it, but in my mind those are some of the most Hawaiian flavors.
